The campus safety is very good, because they have a system which text messages every student at the school if something goes wrong, called the 'BC Alert' system. There are also 'call boxes' for emergencies all around the school, as well as local patrolling security during all hours.
None, as far as I know of.

I've seen a great amount of unique types of clubs and activities in the school, one of my favorite being the 'Brain Buster' club which partakes in active trivia for scholarship money. It's a lot of fun.

Hard working students who are not afraid of a very open campus with lots of people to talk to and meet. Social people will also love this campus. It's also a great place to try many different types of things, so it's very hard for me to think of types of students whom it will NOT be good for.

Because of the large selection of classes and high quality of specialized classes, this is really an incredible financial option for the AA degree seeker. Broward College now offers some BA degrees as well, which they even have special financing for certain majors, as there is a high demand for certain types of work in South Florida, and you may way to look into if your looking for some spare cash.

They often have community events at the school, where they have DJs, performers, and free food available very often in the heart of the school grounds. There are also a lot of free musical and theater events for students, as well as visits from politicians like Michelle Obama, which happened just two days ago.

A very decent cafeteria, they have a very healthy/delicious meat and vegetable wrap center. At the hot food area, the pizza is pretty gross , however I like the Jamaican Beef patties. I've seen ads that they are developing a bunch of local healthy food chains into the school within a year, so when that comes up I think it will deserve 4 stars.

There really aren't dorms in this community college, I do not know many that there are, but there are apartments being developed on the same street as the campus for those who wish to live right on the school.

Many classes are very difficult, which is truly what you want in a community college, as you will actually learn about the subject you are studying. Be prepared to work, and the harder you work the more benefits you reap.

Research your professors beforehand, because there are fantastic ones and terrible ones. The education is in the professor, not the institution. Always be striving to discover your passion if you haven't already, it's the one thing you truly need to know before graduating.

A big school with lots of opportunities, and lots of friends to make. There are great professors, and some mediocre, so do your research and homework before signing up for everything. Take the time and go to your advisers and financial aid offices, to make sure you're making the most of your time and money at Broward College.

textAfterTable: Am enjoying being here Broward College may be a 4 year school, but this is not where I am destined to graduate from. I am very grateful for the education that I am currently receiving, but for the price of admission and classes I strongly disagree with the amount of learning resources available. The students need more technology in the classrooms to have visual reference to the subjects in question. Aside from the lack of technology, Broward College is another mediocre public college that accomplishes what it's aimed to do. Am learning a lot Although Broward College is a great campus for the locals residing in South Florida, I've come to notice that many professors do not posses the required discipline, and lecture skills, to be qualified as a professor. Broward College offers many different classes at different hours of the day, which is convenient for many working students. From my own personal experience, however, I conclude that a minority of professors do not appear in class with their resources prepared, and fail to carry out the ideal lectures aimed to keep the student's interest afloat.
